Problem:
Consider a sequence of complex transformations applied to a function \\(h(z)\\) in the complex plane, described by \\(h_1(z) = e^{Az}h(z)\\) initially and then \\(h_2(z) = e^{Bz}h_1(z)\\) after some time T, where A and B are complex constants.

If the transformations \\(h_1(z)\\) and \\(h_2(z)\\) are applied sequentially to a function \\(h(z)\\) as described, will the final function \\(h_2(T)\\) at time T be equal to directly applying a single transformation \\(e^{(A+B)T}h(z)\\)?
Explanation: The sequential application of the transformations leads to compositional action which is analogous to exponential addition in the exponents due to the properties of exponential functions in the complex plane, ultimately equating to a single exponential transformation of the sum of constants A and B over time T.
